content.webTitle: Monday briefing: Johnson must 'answer difficult questions'

fields.headline: Monday briefing: Johnson must 'answer difficult questions'
fields.bodyText: Top story: ‘Don’t be a coward’ Good morning and welcome to this first briefing of the week with Alison Rourke. Boris Johnson will come under pressure today to respond to calls from inside his own party to explain an incident with his girlfriend on Friday night at her London flat. His Tory leadership rival, Jeremy Hunt, says he “needs to show he can answer difficult questions”. It follows cabinet ministers, backbenchers and major party donors demanding an explanation about the late-night altercation that was heard by several neighbours. Hunt has accused Johnson of appearing willing to “slink through the back door” of No 10 by “pathetically” evading questioning. “Don’t be a coward Boris, man up,” he wrote in today’s edition of the Times, calling on him to stop avoiding public scrutiny. One Tory donor, who has given more than £500,000, told the Guardian that the issue was damaging the party. “We are a laughing stock,” he said. Johnson’s column in the Daily Telegraph this morning was silent on the incident, with the former foreign secretary preferring to focus on his bid to get the UK out of Europe by Halloween. Johnson is due to take part in a digital hustings with Tory party members today and has refused to say if he will face Hunt in a televised Sky News debate on Tuesday. * * * Istanbul’s ‘new page’ – Turkey’s biggest city has dealt a heavy blow to the president, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, delivering a landslide victory to another party’s candidate in his home city’s mayoral elections. The vote – a re-run of the 31 March poll which was also won by Ekrem İmamoğlu from the People’s Republican party, but cancelled by the electoral board – is being seen as a landmark because many feared democracy was failing. “We are starting a new page in Istanbul,” İmamoğlu told supporters. “Today 16 million Istanbullus have refreshed our belief in democracy.” His election will be seen as a blow for Erdoğan, who built his political career in the city in the 1990s. * * * US-Iran – Donald Trump says Tehran’s “absolutely broken” economy will face “major” new sanctions on Monday. It comes as Iran has insisted it would step up its nuclear program unless Europe does more to shield the country from American pressure. Tensions remain high in the Gulf, despite Washington calling off airstrikes that had been planned in reprisal to the downing of a US drone on Thursday. John Bolton, Trump’s hawkish national security adviser, warned Iran not to mistake US prudence for weakness. * * * Brexit’s global Britain? – The government must make it easier for Indians to come to Britain to secure a post-Brexit trade deal, MPs from the cross-party Commons foreign affairs committee say. The group has told ministers they must either ease migration rules with one of the world’s fastest growing economies, or be honest that tough controls will kill off the prospect of a “global Britain” trading around the world after Brexit. It comes as a new report suggests the Irish border issue that has befuddled Brexit could be resolved within three years in the event of no-deal or the collapse of future trade talks with the EU. The report – to be unveiled by the Alternative Arrangements Commission on Monday – suggests special economic zones “covering frontier traffic and national security offer potentially valuable solutions”, which could respect the realities of the border. But it would require buy-in from the DUP, something they have so far opposed. * * * Gambling addiction – The first NHS gambling clinic for children is opening amid growing concern that the rise of online gaming sites and targeted adverts is fuelling a problem among young people. There are 55,000 children classed as having a gambling problem in the UK, according to the Gambling Commission, which also found that 450,000 are gambling regularly – more than those who have taken drugs, drunk alcohol or smoked. Simon Stevens, the NHS England chief executive, said: “This action shows just how seriously the NHS takes the threat of gambling addiction, even in young people. * * * Sperm in space – All-female astronaut crews could reproduce without the help of accompanying men, new research suggests. The study found that frozen samples of sperm exposed to microgravity retained similar characteristics to sperm samples kept on the ground, raising hopes that a sperm bank could one day be set up in space to help populate new worlds, including potentially on Mars. Today in Focus podcast: What has changed since the Stonewall rebellion? The Stonewall rebellion in 1969 started a revolution in LGBT rights in the US. Ed Pilkington revisits the story 50 years on with those who were there. Plus: Lucy Seigle on the rise of fast fashion. Lunchtime read: The new armpit hair revolution Female body hair is making a comeback, writes Rebecca Thus-Dubrow. But today’s renewed enthusiasm for female hirsuteness comes with a distinctly 21st-century twist. Unshaven women in 2019 often meet other criteria for traditional feminine beauty – they have sculpted eyebrows, wear lipstick or sexy lingerie – while proudly displaying their armpit hair. If the ethos of the 70s was a refusal to spend time and effort on cosmetics, the more common approach today is for women to curate different elements of their appearance, remaining conventionally attractive while deploying body hair as a feminist fuck-you: half-statement, half-ornament. Sport England’s women are through to the last eight of the World Cup after a bruising encounter with Cameroon that left coach Phil Neville fuming about how the African team had “shamed football”. Neville said: “I’m completely and utterly ashamed of the opposition and their behaviour.” In the other last-16 tie, France scored an extra-time winner to defeat Brazil 2-1. Andy Murray marked his return to competitive tennis by winning the men’s doubles title at Queen’s with Feliciano López, but he will partner Frenchman Pierre-Hugues Herbert when he targets the Wimbledon title next week. South Africa are out of the Cricket World Cup after losing by 49 runs to Pakistan at Lord’s while England’s Jofra Archer will put his friendship with Australia’s Steve Smith to one side when they clash at headquarters tomorrow. And Australian rugby star Israel Folau has had his fundraising page for his legal challenge against Rugby Australia over a homophobic social media post taken down for breaching GoFundMe’s terms of service. Business The tensions in the Middle East saw the price of oil rise in early trade on Monday, with a barrel of Brent crude up 0.6% to $65.58. Asia Pacific stocks were lower but the threat of sanctions against Iran rather than a full-scale military intervention by the US kept prices from plunging. At home, a new report has found that most forms of Brexit will worsen the country’s finances and reduce space for new initiatives to address child poverty, social care and left-behind communities that some argue drove the Brexit vote. The report by academics at the UK in a Changing Europe thinktank said: “Most forms of Brexit will worsen the government’s fiscal position, probably significantly, reducing the space for new policy initiatives.” The pound is buying €1.120 and and $1.275. The papers Boris Johnson’s attempts to deflect questions about his domestic disharmony seem not to be working as several papers have him being urged to “come clean” about what went on. The Guardian has: “Hunt piles pressure on Johnson over police visit”. The Times reports: “Johnson is a coward, says Hunt”. The Express says: “Pressure on Boris to come clean” and the i has: “Johnson urged to deal with domestic row”. The Mail is more sympathetic to the Tory leadership contender: “Boris and girlfriend driven out of home”, as is the Telegraph, which runs a write-off of his weekly column as its lead story: “Boris: I won’t bottle Brexit”. The Mirror quotes anonymous “pals” who say that “Boris ‘wants to get back with his wife’”, and the Sun has its own anonymous friends who say: “Boris and Carrie 4 rows in 6 wks”. The FT, the only paper not to splash on Boris Johnson today, has: “Lloyds froze 8,000 accounts amid offshore dirty-money crackdown”.
